Hey mentors, I have big news!

I just finished standardizing how arbalest-simple QStyleSheet is interpreted on Linux (Ubuntu 24.04.1 LTS) and on Windows (Windows 11)! Obviously these reworked style and themes were created keeping in mind the soon-to-be feature to support theme creation/editing directly from the app.

Also, even bigger news, I just finished implementing and testing support forchanging themes at runtime without closing and reopening the app!
Images and videos of these changes can be seen on my logs.
Tomorrow I will create the PR for this code (probably separated into 2-3 PRs).

I have found only one problem that I need some help with: adding icons through the QStyleSheet.

Basically, the "x" icon to close a document and a down arrow icon that I added for the ComboBox, are added with the following code inside the QStyleSheet:

#documentAreaTabBar::close-button {
    image: url(:/icons/sadeep_created_close-tab.png);
}

QComboBox::down-arrow {
    image: url(:/icons/baseline_down_arrow_black_48dp.png);
}

The goal is to make these 2 icons' colors modifiable (consistently with all the other icons). Unfortunately there is no way to cleanly achieve this.

From outside the QStyleSheet I haven't found a way to easily set these images.

The only way to do this apparently is to use QStyle, but QStyle and QStyleSheet cohabitation is a dangerous situation.

And from the docs:

Warning:Qt style sheets are currently not supported for custom QStyle subclasses. We plan to address this in some future release.

From inside the QStyleSheet, there isn't a way to read images from data, but only from a path to a file.

This means that the only solution seems to be the following:

  • open the QIcon
  • use QPixmap to change its color
  • write the modified icon to disk
  • make theQStyleSheet read the modified icon from disk
Any feedback regarding this situation is greatly appreciated!

:thinking: Why are these icons different from the others?
There are only two versions of each icon, couldn't be both present as file?

However, :/icons/sadeep_created_close-tab.png isn't a file, but a resource path. You could have a look at QResource:

This can often be useful when loading a large set of application icons that may change based on a setting, or that can be edited by a user and later recreated.

QStyleSheet may not be able to read images from data, but maybe from Base64 encoded strings like

data:image/png;base64, iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAUAAAAFCAYAAACNbyblAAAAHElEQVQI12P4//8/w38GIAXDIBKE0DHxgljNBAAO9TXL0Y4OHwAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==

These 2 icons are different from the other ones because they are set within the stylesheet using:

image: url(:/icons/image_name.png);

While all the other icons are set using:

QIcon icon;
setIcon(icon.addPixmap(QPixmap::fromImage(coloredIcon(":/icons//image_name.png", "$Color-Icon"))));

This means that there is no easy way to color these icons (like coloredIcon() does), because these images can only be referenced from their path only.

There is no way to read the image, change its color accordingly to the theme, and then set this modified icon through image:.

The only way to do this seems to be to save the modified icon to disk, and then modify the icon path that image: reads
I did some reasearch and from my understanding QStyleSheet does not support Base64 encoded images...

I see what you mean, but I'm not sure if this is the way we should go. With coloredIcon()only two-color icons can be used, which is a bit limiting for the future. Is there a reason, why we shouldn't use simply two sets of icons, one for the light and one for the dark theme?
The idea is to make it so that a user can modify the color of any icon whichever way he wants
The theme creation / editing feature will allow the user to modify the colors of every UI component directly from within the app

Keeping two sets of icons for light and dark themes only makes sense if the application will only have the standard light and dark themes. If we want the user to also create its own theme, then he will not be able to modify the buttons icons colors

Imo giving the user complete freedom on how he wants the app to look while also keeping only 1 set of icons that can appear in whichever color the user wants (instead of 2 sets with fixed color) is really good

Hey @Daniel Rossberg , sorry for not being communicative in the past days. I had an exam on Friday 20th, and I thought I could prepare for the exam and work at the same time... guess that wasn't a really smart idea, and now I feel pretty burned out ahah
Anyway, I actually did some work, and I wanted to talk to you regarding the next steps for the project

Arbalest style guide

First of all, I would love to make it so that arbalest's code follows a style guide. Maybe it's just a pet peeve of mine, but I feel that the coderight now is pretty messy, and, at least for me, messy code = less coding efficiency.

My goal with my proposed style guide was not to dictate a style guide without any prior discussion. On the contrary, the goal was to spark said discussion. So any feedback from anyone regarding the coding style for arbalest is appreciated.

Anyhow, I also feel that this issue should be really low priority (at least in relation to my GSoC project), so I will slowly work on it while I work on higher priority stuff.

Arbalest stylesheet and themes

Regarding arbalest stylesheet and themes, I feel like I have achieved the 3 goals present in my GSoC proposal:

  1. revert the hacks done to create a personalized title bar and use the standard Qt title bar instead
  2. fix how themes work with the goal of making them appear correctly on all OS
  3. support runtime theme changes (without having to close and reopen the application)

Feature to create and modify themes

It is obvious that more discussion is needed on how best to implement this feature (and whether this feature should be implemented in the first place).

In any case this feature will be the least interesting among those that I submitted in my GSoC proposal.

So, if my mentors agree, I would prefer not to tackle this feature right now, but work on it at the end of the GSoC program.

Arbalest's new Command Line Interface (CLI)

The "qged-like" Command Line Interface for arbalest is the key feature of my proposal, and it's what I've been working on for the past few days.

I would love to have a functioning prototype for this feature before the Midterm Evaluation.

So, if my mentors agree, I would prefer to tackle the new CLI right now.

Your exams are of course a top priority for you, and it's understood that you can pause your project because of these. GSoC gives students the possibility to adjust their timeline according. I just wanted to make sure that no action from my side is required.

programming style guide
I can understand your demand for a style guide, but because of its far-reaching consequences, I don't want to decide it in passing. I have however to ask for some patience, because I'm traveling a lot at the moment (on business). I plan to open a thread here on Zulip regarding hacking rules for arbalest.

arbalest themes
As far as I understood, there a some things which can only be done with Qt style sheets but not with QStyle. This complicates the change of the theme at runtime. My suggestion was to move to pure Qt style sheet themes, but I'm not a big style creator. Therefore, this is not a decision but only a mention that the change at runtime has no priority for me. I agree with your suggestion that you should keep thinking about it but start working on the next topic.

command line interface

I might have a plan for how to create the CLI in a clean and "simple" (meaning that it will be very simple to understand and clean, but it will be a lot of work to achieve) way. I would love some honest and hard feedback regarding this.

MOOSE

On MOOSE's side of things, the module CommandString will have many more "ged wrappers".

"CompleteCommand" will, given a char * (or a std::string, or a QString, or a list of one of those), act like a wrapper for ged_cmd_completions.

"CompleteGeometry" will be pretty much the same as "CompleteCommand", but for ged_geom_completions.

This same idea will apply also for ged_cmd_exists, ged_cmd_valid, ged_cmd_lookup, and so on...

Arbalest

On arbalest's side of things, there will be 2 new widgets: Console and ConsoleCompleter.

Console

Console will be initialized in MainWindow::prepareDockables and placed inside a ConsoleDockable that will be positioned in the Qt::BottomDockWidgetArea.

A reference to the Console will be stored inside MainWindow.

Console will need a pointer to the currently active Document (when the active Document is changed, inside MainWindow::onActiveDocumentChanged the setter Console::setActiveDocument will be called with the new active Document as an argument).

The main method Console::keyPressEvent will handle everything pretty similarly to pqImplementation::keyPressEvent. When enter/return is pressed, the Console will check if the command is valid, and if so execute it.

ConsoleCompleter

ConsoleCompleter will work kinda like GEDShellCompleter. It will suggest a command based on what the user has already typed in the Console.

Execution of commands

This is the most important part of the project. When the ged_exec wrapper "Parse" executes a certain ged command, there will be many things happening to both the database and the GUI:

  • some stuff should be printed (eg: "ls") -> Console output
  • some object is added (eg: "make") -> ObjectTree is changed, redraw ObjectTreeWidget, rerender Viewports
  • some object is modified (eg: "p") -> ObjectTree is changed, redraw Properties, rerender Viewports
  • some object is removed (eg: "kill") -> ObjectTree is changed, redraw ObjectTreeWidget, rerender Viewports
  • some object's visibilty is changed (eg: "draw", "erase") -> ObjectTree is changed, redraw ObjectTreeWidget, rerender Viewports
  • other stuff (eg: "quit") -> quit application

Imo it's a bad idea to make it so that the Console should handle all of this complexity by, based on the command executed, calling all the methods to modify the ObjectTree, change objects' visibilty state, redraw the ObjectTreeWidget/Properties if necessary, refresh the GeometryRenderer, rerender the Viewports, and so on.

The best way to handle all this complexity (again, this is my opinion) is to make it so to not "make the GUI handle the ObjectTree", but to "make the ObjectTreehandle the GUI".

I will give an example on what I mean by this statement: let's say that I want to add an "Arb8". I have two ways of doing this:

  • Menu bar -> Create -> Arb8
  • CLI -> "make test arb8"

Both of these ways will modify the database by adding a new object through MOOSE. The first one will use Database::Add and the second one will use CommandString::Parse.

Then, the presence of this new object should modify something in the GUI (again, I'm talking about ObjectTree, ObjectTreeWidget, Viewport, Properties, ...). Instead of making it so that the menu bar QAction or the Console has to call a bunch of stuff to make these things in order (for example when QAction createArb8Act is pressed, it adds and "Arb8", and then calls a bunch of stuff to readjust the GUI accordingly), the ObjectTree itself could handle all of this by:

  1. adding the object to the db

  2. realizing that a new object has been added to the db, so:

    - the new object should be present in the object tree widget
    - the new object visibilty state should be "visible"
    - the new object should be selected
    - ...

  3. realizing that an object is now "visible", so:

    - the object should be drawn
    - the object should be seen as "visible" in the object tree widget
    - the object's parent should be seen as "has children visible" in the object tree widget
    - ...

  4. realizing that an object is now "selected", so:

    - the object should be seen as selected in the object tree widget
    - the object properties should appear in the properties dockable
    - ...

  5. ...

So basically the ObjectTree will modifiy its database and its internal properties (eg: objectIdVisibilityStateMap), and then modify the GUI accordingly. This way all the GUI parts of arbalest will be much cleaner and more related to GUI stuff, while ObjectTree will be the most "complex and low level" part of arbalest, that will handle 99% of the calls to the underlying MOOSE's/brlcad's stuff.

Also... I'm just realizing that QgConsole could simply be used. QgConsole will handle the console stuff, and then emit a signal when a command should be executed, and then that command could be passed to MOOSE

So basically libqtcad's QgConsole can be reused (and this will also hide the complexity regarding the console), MOOSE will handle the execution of ged commands (and other ged-related stuff), and all the complexity regarding handling database changes (and their effect on the GUI) will be stuffed inside ObjectTree
Is this a good plan? Is it feasible? Will this maintain arbalest's clean implementation? Am I missing something? I'm sure that I must be overlooking something...

Hmm, interesting. What I found out so far:
It looks like rt_db_put_internal() in GED_DB_PUT_INTERNAL (include/ged/objects.h) fails for inmem databases. I was able to trace it down to line 120 in src/librt/db5_alloc.c if (dp->d_flags & RT_DIR_INMEM) {, where the inmem flag is not set, and therefore the alloc fails. But, why?

For simple tests, you can build MOOSE/Examples und modify PrintTitle.cpp according your needs.
Interesting, I guessed that it was a problem regarding the MemoryDatabase.

The object creation with the C++ API works, e.g. with arbalest's creation menu.

The directory structure is a temporary pointer to a database object. Where does it get the database type information from :thinking:

If my understanding is correct, when arbalest calls MemoryDatabase::Add, the method:

  • checks for the object's validity
  • checks the object's type id
  • wdb_export "writes" the correct object type inside the database
  • db_lookup gets a reference to the written object
  • this reference is used to modify its attributes to the correct ones
And libged's make command uses db_diradd and rt_db_get_internal.

oh, it's (inside db_diradd):

dp->d_flags = flags & ~(RT_DIR_INMEM);
so, it was intentionally not handling in-memory databases, because it was never tested for them?

Not "intentionally", but untested is likely. Inmem databases haven't been made robust across the whole API because their handling is a bit different. They work for large swaths of commands and API, but there are plenty of places untested or not yet considered.
Mmh got it, very interesting. So the right way to go is to test inmem dbs for the make command (and I guess other ged commands), correct?

It is the intention that they should work anywhere a dbip is taken, so the only appreciable difference to a caller is whether they used db_open_inmem() or db_open(). Even some of the parallel API like like db_dirbuild_inmem() probably shouldn't exist (but currently do for that special handling).
